Unlike "True Lilies" (Lilium spp.), they do not cause fatal kidney failure in cats. The plant—especially the bulb—contains toxins that primarily affect the gastrointestinal tract.
1. Vomiting and Diarrhea
1. Symptom Name: Vomiting and Diarrhea (Gastrointestinal Upset).
2. Affected Body System: Gastrointestinal.
3. Severity: Mild to Moderate.
4. Typical Onset Time: Acute (Typically within a few hours of ingestion).
5. Additional Clinical Notes: Ingestion of any part of the plant can cause these symptoms, but the bulb (corm) is the most toxic part and causes the most severe reactions.

2. Excessive Drooling (Hypersalivation)
1. Symptom Name: Drooling / Salivation.
2. Affected Body System: Gastrointestinal / Oral.
3. Severity: Mild.
4. Typical Onset Time: Acute (Immediate to shortly after chewing/ingestion).
5. Additional Clinical Notes: This occurs due to the plant's irritant properties on the mouth and digestive tract. Gladioli belong to the Iridaceae (Iris) family, which are known to cause oral and mucosal irritation when eaten.
    ◦ Sources:1,3
3. Lethargy
1. Symptom Name: Lethargy.
2. Affected Body System: Neurological / General Systemic.
3. Severity: Mild to Moderate.
4. Typical Onset Time: Acute (Accompanying gastrointestinal symptoms).
5. Additional Clinical Notes: The cat may appear tired or disinterested in food due to the abdominal discomfort and nausea associated with the poisoning.

4. Abdominal Pain
1. Symptom Name: Abdominal Pain.
2. Affected Body System: Gastrointestinal.
3. Severity: Moderate.
4. Typical Onset Time: Acute.

Question: What are the recommended veterinary treatments if a cat ingests Gladioli / Sword Lily? List them in order of priority (most urgent first). For each treatment provide: 1. Treatment name. 2. Brief description of the procedure. 3. Any situation-specific notes. Cite your sources.
============================================================

Based on the provided sources, Gladioli (also known as Sword Lily or Gladiolus spp.) are classified as "Imposter Lilies" or gastrointestinal irritants. Unlike "True Lilies," they do not cause fatal kidney failure, but the bulbs (corms) are toxic and can cause severe gastrointestinal upset.
Here are the recommended veterinary treatments in order of priority:
1. Symptomatic and Supportive Care
• Treatment Name: Pharmacological Symptom Management (Anti-emetics and Antidiarrheals).
• Brief description of the procedure: Veterinarians administer medications to control the primary symptoms of poisoning. Anti-emetics are given to stop vomiting, and antidiarrheals are used to manage diarrhea. A bland diet may be prescribed for several days to soothe the digestive tract during recovery.
• Situation-specific notes: Because Gladioli act primarily as gastrointestinal irritants, the goal is to stabilize the cat and prevent further fluid loss. Most animals recover within 24–48 hours with this support.
    ◦ Sources:1
2. Fluid Therapy
• Treatment Name: Intravenous (IV) or Subcutaneous Fluid Administration.
• Brief description of the procedure: If the cat has experienced significant vomiting or diarrhea, the veterinarian will administer fluids to correct dehydration and restore electrolyte balance.
• Situation-specific notes: This is particularly important if the cat is lethargic or has been unable to keep water down. Maintaining hydration helps flush toxins and supports general organ function.
    ◦ Sources:2,1
3. Gastrointestinal Decontamination (Emesis)
• Treatment Name: Induction of Emesis (Vomiting).
• Brief description of the procedure: If the ingestion was very recent (typically within 1–2 hours) and the cat is asymptomatic, the veterinarian may induce vomiting to remove the plant material (especially the toxic bulbs) from the stomach before the toxins are fully absorbed.
• Situation-specific notes: This should never be attempted at home using hydrogen peroxide, as it can cause severe irritation and injury to cats. It must be performed by a veterinary professional.
    ◦ Sources:2,3
4. Oral Decontamination and Soothing
• Treatment Name: Oral Rinsing and Demulcents.
• Brief description of the procedure: If the cat is drooling excessively or showing signs of oral irritation (common with plants in the Iridaceae family), the vet may rinse the mouth to remove plant residue. They may also administer demulcents (soothing agents) or dairy products (like milk) to bind crystals and soothe the mucous membranes.
• Situation-specific notes: While less common for Gladioli than for plants with insoluble oxalates (like Dieffenbachia), oral irritation can occur.
    ◦ Sources:4,5
